TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit PropertyDescriptorCollection extends System.Object implements class System.Collections.ICollection, class System.Collections.IDictionary, class System.Collections.IEnumerable, class System.Collections.IList

Docs.summary: Represents a collection of objects.

remarks.format:
## Remarks PropertyDescriptorCollection is read-only; it does not implement methods that add or remove properties. You must inherit from this class to implement these methods.
Using the properties available in the PropertyDescriptorCollection class, you can query the collection about its contents. Use the <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptorCollection.Count%2A> property to determine the number of elements in the collection. Use the [Item\<xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptorCollection.Item%2A> property to get a specific property by index number or by name.
In addition to properties, you can use the <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptorCollection.Find%2A> method to get a description of the property with the specified name from the collection.
## Examples The following code example creates a new PropertyDescriptorCollection using the properties on `button1`. It requires that `button1` has been instantiated on a form.
[!code-cs[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CSharp/t-system.componentmodel._39_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CPP/t-system.componentmodel._39_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/t-system.componentmodel._39_1.vb)]
The next example prints all the properties on a button in a text box. It requires that `button1` and `textBox1` have been instantiated on a form.
[!code-cs[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection Example#2](~/add/codesnippet/CSharp/t-system.componentmodel._39_2.cs)] [!code-cpp[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection Example#2](~/add/codesnippet/CPP/t-system.componentmodel._39_2.cpp)] [!code-vb[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection Example#2](~/add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/t-system.componentmodel._39_2.vb)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use the Count property to set the limits of a loop that iterates through a collection of objects. Because the collection is zero-based, be sure to use `Count - 1` as the upper boundary of the loop.
## Examples The following code example uses the Count property to print the number of properties on `button1`. It requires that `button1` and `textBox1` have been instantiated on a form.
[!code-vb[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.Count Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/p-system.componentmodel._29_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.Count Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CPP/p-system.componentmodel._29_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.Count Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CSharp/p-system.componentmodel._29_1.cs)]

Docs.summary: Specifies an empty collection that you can use instead of creating a new one with no items. This field is read-only.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example finds a specific <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor>. It prints the type of component for this <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor> in a text box. It requires that `button1` and `textBox1` have been instantiated on a form.
[!code-cs[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.Find Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CSharp/9cbbd46a-64d4-4a04-8109-_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.Find Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CPP/9cbbd46a-64d4-4a04-8109-_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.Find Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/9cbbd46a-64d4-4a04-8109-_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig instance void InternalSort(string[] names) cil managed

Docs.param: An array of strings describing the order in which to sort the objects in this collection.
Docs.summary: Sorts the members of this collection. The specified order is applied first, followed by the default sort for this collection, which is usually alphabetical.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example defines the sort order for the InternalSort method. If the <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptorCollection> contains four <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor> objects with the names `A`, `B`, `C`, and `D`, the properties of `myNewColl` would be sorted in the order `D`, `B`, `A`, and `C`.
[!code-cs[Classic EventDescriptorCollection.InternalSort Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CSharp/362da624-49d1-447a-bc3b-_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[Classic EventDescriptorCollection.InternalSort Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CPP/362da624-49d1-447a-bc3b-_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[Classic EventDescriptorCollection.InternalSort Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/362da624-49d1-447a-bc3b-_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor this[int index] { get; }

Docs.param: The zero-based index of the to get or set.
Docs.summary: Gets or sets the at the specified index number.
Docs.value: The with the specified index number.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The index number is zero-based. Therefore, you must subtract 1 from the numerical position of a particular <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor> to access that <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor>. For example, to get the third <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor>, you need to specify `myColl[2]`.
## Examples The following code example uses the Item property to print the name of the <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor> specified by the index number in a text box. Because the index number is zero-based, this example prints the name of the second <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor>. It requires that `button1` has been instantiated on a form.
[!code-cpp[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.this Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CPP/p-system.componentmodel._18_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.this Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CSharp/p-system.componentmodel._18_1.cs)] [!code-vb[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.this Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/p-system.componentmodel._18_1.vb)]

Docs.exception: The parameter is not a valid index for Item.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor this[string name] { get; }

Docs.param: The name of the to get from the collection.
Docs.summary: Gets or sets the with the specified name.
Docs.value: The with the specified name, or if the property does not exist.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptorCollection.Item%2A> property is case-sensitive when searching for names. That is, the names "Pname" and "pname" are considered to be two different properties.
## Examples The following code example uses the <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptorCollection.Item%2A> property to print the type of component for the <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor> specified by the index. It requires that `button1` and `textBox1` have been instantiated on a form.
[!code-cpp[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.this1 Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CPP/p-system.componentmodel._19_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.this1 Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/p-system.componentmodel._19_1.vb)] [!code-cs[Classic PropertyDescriptorCollection.this1 Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/CSharp/p-system.componentmodel._19_1.cs)]
